He wants a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production. His main priority from the profits of the business is to pay school fees for his children. 

Note: This photo of Jean Baptiste was taken by his banana plantation, not his maize plantation.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 42 years old, married and blessed with five children aged between fourteen and one. She has been selling second hand clothes for the last three years, making a monthly income of 5,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). 

Monica has applied for her first loan of 20,000 KES from KADET LTD, which she plans to use to purchase more bales of clothes so that she can meet the demands of her customers during the high season.

The anticipated profits will be diversified into some potato farming. Her future plans are to grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: to purchase used clothes for resale

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne is 36 years old, married and blessed with three children aged 14, 13 and 9 years respectively. She runs a retail shop, a business she has been in for the past 10 years, and earns a monthly income of 15,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).
 
She has requested a first loan of KES 30,000 to purchase five bags of sugar, 10 bales of maize flour and five bales of wheat flour. 

The profit she earns will be plowed back into her business. Her dream is to see her family excel in life.

loans.use: To purchase five bags of sugar, 10 bales of maize flour and five bales of wheat flour.

loans.name: Ide

texts.en:
Ide, 40, is married and lives at West Point. Her husband is a driver. Ide is a mother of five children; her children are between the ages of 8 and 23. Two of them are in school, but the other three children are not attending school because she lacks financial support. 

She has been selling ground peas and bananas for the past 12 years. She received help from her sister to start this business. She is proud of her business because with the profit generated from the business, she contributes to the home and buys more goods to improve the business. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more ground peas and bananas to increase her sales. Her plan is to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more ground peas and bananas to increase her sales.

loans.name: Fudia

texts.en:
This is 41-year-old Fudia. She is single and has one child aged 15 years. She has no additional dependents, but does have two sales assistants who are paid by month.

In 2007, Fudia established her food and drinks business. She began her business as her own means of getting revenue. Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 1,500,000 Le (Sierra Leone leones) every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 6,000,000. Fudia requires a loan in order to buy cooking utensils and some soft drinks. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 1,000,000. In the future, she hope to expand her restaurant as she has more customers now and hopes to realize more profit. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy cooking utensils and some soft drinks.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 60 years old, married to Lokaala, and blessed with three children aged 23, 20 and 18 years respectively.  He runs a boutique, a business he ventured into seven years ago, and earns a monthly income of KES. 31,000. 

He has requested a second loan of KES. 50,000 to purchase childrenswear, shoes and shawls to sell in his boutique. The profits he earns will help him take care of the family’s needs.

He dreams of being a successful businessman in this region.

loans.use: to purchase childrenswear, shoes and shawls to sell in his boutique.

loans.name: Peace's Group

texts.en:
Peace is the leader of a group comprised of two hard working young women. She is 19 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Peace has been working hard to manage her small business, where she sells fish. 

To help expand her business, Peace has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish for her to sell, and will help Peace to generate greater profits. She hopes that in the future she will be able to pay the school fees of her younger siblings. 

Peace is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy more fish to sell

loans.name: María Milagros

texts.es:
María tiene 27 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos. Vive en casa propia, la cual está ubicada en el Caserío Juan Velasco del Distrito de Tambogrande. María vive en la parte rural  de este distrito. Solo cuenta con servicio básico de luz.

La actividad que desarrolla María es la crianza de ganado ovino contando con 25 cabezas de ganado, los cuales cría engorda y comercializa en el mercado local.  Paralelamente cría aves de corral, cuenta con más de 6 años de experiencia en el manejo de su negocio.

María quiere comprar alimento balanceado para su ganado, además para la compra de alimento para sus aves de corral, y realizar mejoras en el corral para así venderlos a un mejor precio. Es por ello que ha creído conveniente obtener un préstamo de 1500 nuevos soles en Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
María is 27 and lives with her common law partner and has two children.  She lives in her own house located in the Juan Velasco Alvarado settlement in the district of Tambogrande.  Maria lives in the rural area of the district and the only basic service available in the area is power.

She breeds sheep and has 25 sheep that she grows and sells at the local market.  She also breeds poultry and has more than six years of experience in the business.

Maria wants to buy feed for her sheep and poultry as well as make betterments to the barn so she can sell them at better prices, thus she thinks it's convenient to get a loan of 1500 Peruvian nuevos soles with Edpyme Alternativa

loans.use: to buy feed for her livestock and to make betterments to the barn.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy four bails of cotton for her textiles business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Forty-seven-year-old Susan is married, and blessed with four children aged 22, 21, 18 and 16 respectively. She sells fish, a business she started twelve years ago, and earns a monthly income of KES 23, 000. 

She has requested a second loan of KES. 40,000 to purchase more fish to sell. The profit earned from the business will help her buy additional stock. 

Her dream is to see her children well educated, as well as to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Claire

texts.en:
Claire is 16 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Claire has been working hard to manage her small business, where she farms and sells chickens. 

To help expand her business, Claire has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicks, and will help Claire to generate greater profits and expand her poultry business. Claire hopes that in the future she will be able to pay school fees for her younger siblings. 

Claire is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and expand her poultry business.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is 33 years old, married to Moses, and is blessed with four children aged 13, 8, 5 and 2. She started her business four years ago, selling cloth fabric materials, as well as charcoal. She earns a monthly income of KES. 26,400. 

Selina has requested a second loan of KES. 60,000 to purchase cloth fabric materials to sell. The anticipated profits will help her to buy additional stock for her business. 

Her dream is to one day purchase a piece of land and build rental houses for additional income.

loans.use: to purchase cloth fabric materials to sell.

loans.name: Edith

texts.es: Edith, de 28 años, es una mujer joven, trabajadora y muy responsable, es madre soltera y enfrenta el mundo con valor y fuerza por el bienestar de su único hijo de 9 años, ella vive en casa de su madre junto a su hermana y su menor hijo, ella trabaja mucho día a día para poder brindarle lo mejor a su niño. El trabajo de Edith consiste en la venta al por menor de productos de primera necesidad, entre los que se encuentran; arroz, azúcar, leche, panes, huevos, aceite, verduras y mas. Este negocio lo tiene en su casa en donde atiende todos los días y a tiempo completo. Lleva trabajando por 11 años en este rubro. Al inicio tuvo la ayuda de su madre pero ahora el negocio es solo de ella y recibe la ayuda de su hermana en algunas ocasiones cuando ella tiene que cumplir otras funciones fuera de casa. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que tiene tiempo para cumplir otras actividades eventuales, afortunadamente le va muy bien ya que siempre tienen clientes debido a la variedad de productos que ofrece y porque además en la única bodega en su barrio, espera poder seguir surgiendo y hacer crecer su negocio. Este es el préstamo número 5 con MFP, está muy agradecida por la oportunidad crediticia que le brindan y por el respaldo financiero que necesita para seguir adelante. Se compromete a pagar sus cuotas mensuales de manera puntual y continuar trabajando con mucha responsabilidad junto a los miembros de su banco comunal. Con el monto solicitado 2500 soles, comprará mercadería para su venta en su bodega conformada por golosinas, arroz, azúcar, panes, huevos, leche, aceites verduras y otros
texts.en:
Edith is a 28-year-old young woman. She is a hardworking and responsible single mother, and faces the world with courage and strength for the wellbeing of her only child, who is nine years old. She lives in her mother's house, along with her sister and her son. She works a lot day after day to be able to provide her boy with the best.

Edith's work consists of the retail sale of basic products, including rice, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, oil, vegetables, and more. She runs this business in her house, where she works full-time every day. She has been in this line of work for 11 years. 

In the beginning, she had her mother's help, but now the business is all hers. She sometimes gets help from her sister when she has business to take care of away from home. What she likes about her work is that she has time to deal with other issues that crop up. Fortunately, it's going very well since she always has customers due to the variety of products she sells and because hers is the only shop in the neighborhood. 

Edith hopes to continue developing and growing her business. This is her fifth loan with MFP, and she is very grateful for the credit opportunity that they provide and for the financial support that she needs to carry on. She promises to pay her monthly payments in a timely manner and to continue working responsibly with the members of her communal bank. With the requested amount of 2,500 soles (PEN), she will buy merchandise to sell in her shop, including snacks, rice, sugar, bread, eggs, milk, oil, vegetables, and more.

loans.use: to buy snacks, rice, sugar, bread, eggs, milk, oil, and vegetables.

loans.name: Flavia

texts.en:
Flavia is 19 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Flavia has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells airtime and phone accessories. 

To help expand her business, Flavia has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a refrigerator for her side business, and will help Flavia to generate greater profits and expand her businesses to earn more. Flavia hopes that in the future she will be able to have more money to live comfortably. 

Flavia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator for her side business.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: This is 43-year-old Mohammed. He lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He is an employee in the electricity association and he requires a loan from AMB in order to buy a new motorbike. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his daily profits. In the future, he plans to increase the number of motorbikes with profit earned and to own a house.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for transportation.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 23 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past two years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her small business, where she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a wider variety of clothes to sell, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and be able to pay school fees for her child. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy a wider variety of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 50. She is married to a farmer and they have two children aged 5 and 20. The oldest goes to school. Josephine is requesting a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs. She plans to pay school fees for her oldest son.The photo was taken at the nearby banana plantation.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena 38, live together with her friend and three children in West Point. She stopped her education in the 11th grade. Of her three children, the youngest is four months old and the oldest is 16. Two of her children are attending  school.  Helena has a warehouse where she sells coal wholesale to her customers. Some difficulties she faces are the rainy season and transporting the goods from the bush to Monrovia. She learned to sell from her mother. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of coals in large quantities to improve the business. She plan to give her children higher level of education.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of coals in large quantities to improve the business.

loans.name: Frenady

texts.en:
Frenady is 41 years old. She is a widow who takes care of five children. All of the children go to school. She has been a maize farmer for 15 years. She would like a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs. She is dedicated to supporting her children in schooling with the profits that will be obtained from the business.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
This is 44 year-old Zainab. She is a widow with 2 children aged 22 and 16. In 1998, Zainab established her foodstuffs business. She began her business because she wanted to fight poverty and to have a source of revenue with which to educate her children. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,800,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Zainab requires a loan in order to buy SLL 3,000,000 worth of foodstuffs. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 1,000,000. In the future, Zainab plans to rent a shop so that she can sell wholesale since she can now reach more customers. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy SLL 3,000,000 worth of foodstuffs.

loans.name: Cosmas

texts.en:
Cosmas is 28 years old, married and blessed with three children ages seven, four and two-years-old respectively. He has run a motorbike transport business for the last year earning a monthly income of KES. 13.000. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 86,300 from KADET LTD. He plans to purchase his own motorbike. The anticipated profits will help him to buy another motorcycle. His future dream is to prosper in business.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Felicite

texts.en:
Felicite is 45 years old. She is married to a farmer and they have two children aged 18 and 20 years old. She is requesting a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizer and to support labor costs. The profits from the business will be used for adding more plots of land for cultivation in order to increase her harvest.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is a 31-year-old married man and father of one child. He has been working in jewelry repair and maintenance since 2008.

Bilal is a hard worker, talented, and experienced in his domain. He is well known in the region. He has a good reputation especially concerning his integrity while dealing in such a business.

Bilal's workshop is located in a very important zone centered among the gold retail market. This is very important for the dealers that he is located among in order to deal with their customers' sudden requests.

Bilal applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua, in order to buy gold and start designing, producing, and selling his own hand-made products. This step forward will improve Bilal's earning potential and will encourage him to elevate his working production to a higher level especially since he has the necessary skills requested for this kind of business.

Bilal hopes to open a showroom that will attract a lot of customers and attention to his own hand-made designs.

loans.use: to buy gold and start designing, producing, and selling his own hand-made productions.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 52 years old. He is married to a farmer. He has been a maize farmer for 10 years. He wants a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs. He is planning to reinvest in the farming business more and more for a better future.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Simion

texts.en:
Simion is 34 years old, married to Selina, and blessed with two children aged 14 and seven years, respectively. He sells gold and gold products, a business he started two years ago and earns him KES 32,000 per month. 

He has requested a second loan of KES 60,000 to purchase gold. Profit made will aid him in expanding this business, which is also his dream for the future.

loans.use: to purchase gold for sale.

loans.name: Flor

texts.es:
Flor, de 38 años, es una señora muy amable, responsable y trabajadora, es conviviente con su pareja con quien tiene un hijo de 8 años, ella vive en casa de su cuñado a lado de su hijo, su pareja y la familia de su cuñado, ella trabaja mucho para poder salir adelante y dar lo mejor a su familia. El trabajo de Flor consiste en la venta de comida, ella desde temprano esta muy activa ya que sale a hacer sus compras al mercado y busca los mejores ingredientes para así poder brindar buenos alimentos a sus fieles clientes quienes la buscan siempre por su buena sazón y su trato amable. Ofrece menú al alcance de todos los bolsillos. Tiene un puesto de ventas ubicado en el puerto de pescadores el cual es muy concurrido por la población lo que le permite vender rápido. Lleva haciendo este trabajo por 21 años y recibe la ayuda de su madre con quien comparte las responsabilidades del negocio. Complementa este trabajo alquilando una furgoneta que adquirió hace un año. Le gusta mucho cocinar, creció haciendo esto a lado de su madre y le agrada trabajar junto a ella, además le da tiempo por las tardes para poder realizar otras actividades, sus clientes son fieles y siempre la buscan porque prepara deliciosos y muy variados potajes, ya que no solo  cocina platillos regionales, sino también nacionales. Le va bien y espera poder ampliar su negocio poniendo un negocio estable cerca de su casa y conservar sus clientes. Este es el crédito número 4 con MFP, está muy contento por el apoyo financiero que le están brindando ya que así se sentirá seguro de avanzar con su trabajo, por otro lado se compromete a continuar pagando puntualmente sus cuotas tal como le programen, está muy feliz de pertenecer a su banco comunal ya que todos son muy responsables y solidarios.
Con el monto solicitado 1800 soles, comprara materiales para seguir con su negocio, pues ella necesita nuevas ollas, mas cubiertos y además comprará ingredientes que usa a diario en la preparación de los platillos.
texts.en:
Flor, 38, is a very friendly, responsible and hardworking woman who has lives with her partner with whom she has an 8-year-old son. She lives in her brother-in-law's home along with her son, her partner and her brother-in-law's family. She works hard to get ahead and give her family the best. Flor's work consists in selling food. She is very active from early on in the morning, as she goes to the market to make purchases and looks for the best ingredients in order to offer her loyal customers with the best food. These customers always seek her out for the excellent taste and her friendly customer care. She offers a menu that is accessible to all budgets. 

Flor has a sales stall located at the Puerto de Pescadores which is well frequented and allows her to sell quickly. She has been doing this job for 21 years and receives the help of her mother with whom she shares the responsibilities of the business. She complements this work renting a van which she purchased one year ago. 

Flor very much likes cooking, having grown up doing this alongside her mother, who she enjoys working with. Moreover, it gives her time in the afternoon to perform other activities. Her customers are loyal and always come to her because she prepares delicious and varied stews, not only does she make regional dishes, but national dishes too. The business is going very well, and she hopes to be able to expand her business, setting up a stable business near her home and keep her customers. 

This is Flor’s 4th loan with Microfinanzas Prisma, she is extremely satisfied with the financial support that they are giving her as in this manner she feels confident of progressing with her work. In addition, she has pledged to continue making punctual repayments as scheduled. She is very happy about belonging to this communal bank as everyone is very responsible and supportive. 

With the requested sum of 1,800 Peruvian Nuevos Soles, Flor will buy materials to continue with her business, but she needs new pans, cutlery as well as buy ingredients that she will use on a daily basis to prepare dishes.

loans.use: to buy pans, more cutlery and ingredients to prepare food.

loans.name: Castro

texts.en:
Castro, a repeat client with UGAFODE, is now taking his third loan. The purpose is to pay the third term's school fees for his children. He is grateful to the institution because the school fee loans help his children to study without interruptions or the risk of being sent away from school for half payments. He is able to pay at once and then repay the loan installments using his salary which also caters for the other demanding needs of the family.

He dreams of setting up a business for his wife to supplement the family income to break the over-reliance on the meager salary.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is aged 49. His wife works as a farmer and they have two children. He has been a maize farmer for 15 years. He wants a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs. He would like to use the profits to pay school fees for the children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Evalyn

texts.en:
Evalyn is a thirty-three-year-old single mother of two children living in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling second-hand clothes for nine years and works for ten hours in a day. Like most good mothers she has a dream of educating her children up to the University, building a permanent house and buying land to grow crops. She has challenges of price fluctuation and high cost of transport to the different markets. 

Evalyn is requesting a loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 40 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have both seven children. Five of them go to school. He has been a maize farmer for 20 years. He wants a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for the children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilisers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Isatu  Amadu

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Isatu. She is married and has three children aged 22, 20 and 16 years old. She has two additional dependents who live with her as adopted children. In 2004, Isatu established her assorted-goods business. She began her business because she wanted to be self-reliant and not need her husband's support. Working six days a week and eight hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,0000. Isatu requires a loan in order to buy goods worth SLL 3,000,000. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 800,000. In the future, Isatu plans to  open another sales center for one of her adopted children who has now matured. She thanks you for your kind support.

loans.use: To buy assorted goods.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 53 years old. He is married to a farmer, and has six children who are between nine and 23 years old. All of them go to school. He has been a maize farmer for 20 years. He wants a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs. Paying school fees for his children is the main priority from the profits of the business.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Ezechiel

texts.en:
Ezechiel is aged 53. He is married to a farmer, they have both 10 children. He has been a maize farmer for 15 years. He wants a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production. He wants to use the profits to pay school fees for his children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 27 years old, married, and blessed with three children aged six, four and two years old. She sells fish, a business she started nine years ago, and which earns her a monthly income of KES 30,000.

She has requested a second loan of KES 20,000 to purchase more fish for sale. 

The profit she earns from it will help her build rental house and repay her loan. She dreams of expanding this business and having her children well educated.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for sale.

loans.name: Viviana

texts.es:
Viviana tiene 30 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene tres hijos dependientes. Vive en casa propia,  en el caserío Barrio Libre del Distrito de Tambogrande y cuentan con  servicios básicos como luz eléctrica. 

La actividad que desarrolla Viviana, es la crianza de ganado porcino y aves de corral como actividad principal ya que cuenta con 8 cabezas de ganado ovino, porcino y aves de corral. Se dedica a la crianza de ganado desde hace más de 8 años. Cuenta con el apoyo de su conviviente quien es agricultor y tiene 1,5 ha de tierras de cultivo con mango y arroz. 

Viviana desea comprar alimento balanceado para animales.  Además quiere realizar mejoras en los corrales y mejorar la fachada de su vivienda. Es por ello que ha creído conveniente obtener un préstamo de 2500 nuevos soles en Edpyme Alterntativa.
texts.en:
Viviana, 30, lives with her partner and has three dependent children.  She lives in her own house in the hamlet of Barrio Libre in the district of Tambogrande.  They have basic services such as electric lights.

Viviana's main job is raising pigs and poultry because she has eight heads of sheep and pig, and poultry.  She has raised livestock for more than eight years.  She has the help of her partner, who's a farmer and has 1.5 hectares of cropland planted with mango and rice.

Viviana wants to buy balanced feed for her animals as well as to make improvements in the corrals and the front of her house.  This is why it's advisable for her to get a loan for 2500 soles [PEN] from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy balanced feed for her livestock

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Victoria. She is married and has one child aged 19. She has no additional dependents. In 2007, Victoria established her provisions business. She began her business in order to have a source of revenue and to be able to assist her husband with domestic problems. Working six days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,800,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Victoria requires a loan in order to buy SLL 5,000,000 worth of provisions. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 1,200,000. In the future, Victoria plans to be a leading supplier of provisions. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy provisions for her shop.

loans.name: Leo

texts.en: Leo, 29, is a hardworking man with one child, age four, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He works in a bank. With his salary, he has been able to buy land, where he has planted tea. He has challenges because of price fluctuations, his low salary, and limited land for expansion.  Notwithstanding all the challenges, he intends to buy more land and expand the tea plantings, build a house, and extend his studies. Leo intends to use his loan to buy more land for growing tea.

loans.use: to buy more land for growing tea .

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles operates a pork restaurant and bar. He wants the loan for school fees, so that his children can be educated. He has six children. He works every day of the week to maximize his profits. He hopes to start a pig farm, to cut down on the high costs of having to buy the pigs for slaughter and thus increase his profits. His experience and good customer service has drawn many customers to him. He is committed to repay the loan well.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena, 25, stopped her education in the 4th grade. She is married with two children, aged three and seven, both of whom are attending school. Her husband is a mechanic, and he gave her the initial capital to start in this business. She has been selling toothpaste, sardines, hair grease, biscuits, tissue, milk, and many other items for the past fifteen years.

She is proud of her business because she makes a profit every day. With the profit, she buys goods, and repays her loan. She has requested another loan from BRAC Liberia to purchase more toothpaste, hair grease, milk and biscuits for the business. Her plan for the future is to give her children a better education and build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more toothpaste, hair grease, milk and biscuits for the business.

loans.name: Radhia Group

texts.en:
Radhia is a mature, fifty-year-old woman and is a member of the group Radhia. She lives in Aden, Yemen. She has been selling incense and perfumes for three years. She is a very responsible woman. 

She applied for a loan of 80,000 YER from AMB to buy a swing for children. She hopes to expand her business to get more income.

loans.use: to buy a swing for children.

loans.name: Loud Group

texts.en:
Loud group is made up of two men, aged 34 and 41 years who are involved in tailoring and the sale of maize (corn). They have lived in the same neighborhood for seven years and in 2010 both decided to come together so that they can access loan from Initiative Development Ghana, Kiva's partner in Ghana.

Robert is a 34-year-old tailor with two children but single. He could not marry the children's mother due to family problems. He needs 800 Ghana Cedis to sew school uniforms. He has a sewing contract from one junior high school in his locality to sew students' uniforms.

He took 800 Ghana Cedis in his 4th loan cycle which was used for the same purpose. He uses his profit to take care of his children and reinvests the rest into the business.

Robert and Jacob need a total amount of 1,150 Ghana Cedis to improve their businesses.

loans.use: To buy material to sew school uniforms for a junior high school.

loans.name: Manolo

texts.en:
Working alongside fellow artisan Lucho, Manolo specializes in leather work. He would like to invest in a purchase of raw materials, such as leather, wood, and glass.

Manolo and Lucho have been selling through NOVICA since 2005. This is their story:

Manolo and Lucho come from families with backgrounds in art. "Our work is an artistic creation. We've worked together since 1994, and find it a source of great personal satisfaction. We both strive to transmit beauty and culture in every piece," say the artists. Manolo and Lucho break all preconceived ideas by combining a distinctive Peruvian look with the art of dedicated masters, all beautifully crafted by hand.

"To us, this microcredit means we can innovate new designs and be part of today's decor trends, while at the same time staying true to our essence and preserving traditional hand crafting techniques. Thank you."

Use the link below to view Manolo and Lucho's leather work on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/index.cfm?faid=5069

loans.use: to purchase raw materials such as leather, wood, and glass.

loans.name: Joetta

texts.en:
Joetta is 46 years old and lives in Buchanan. She’s single and has two children aged 13 and 15 years old that live at home and go to school.

For the past two years she has been operating a table where she sells frozen fish, chicken, etc. She is requesting a loan to purchase more frozen fish, chicken, etc. for her business. She hopes to build her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more frozen fish and chicken for her business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 43 years old and lives in Buchanan. She is a high school graduate and has six children between seven and 26 years old; all of them live at home and three are attending school.

For the past twenty years she has been selling rubber dishes (plates, blows, cups, etc.) in the local market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rubber dishes (plates, blows, cups, etc.) for her business. She wishes to build her own house and educate all her children.

loans.use: to purchase more rubber dishes for her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 37 years old and lives in Buchanan. She is married and has three children between the ages of three and 16. 

For the past 16 years she has been running a cook shop (restaurant) in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice and fufu (an African food made of cassava) for her business. She hopes to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more rice and fufu (an African food made of cassava) for her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 49 years old and lives in Buchanan. She is married and has four children between the ages of 12 and 25 who all attend school and live at home.

For three years now she has been selling slippers, blouses and many other items. She started this business with money given to her by her husband. She is requesting a loan to buy slippers, blouses and many other items for her business. She hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy slippers, blouses and many other items for her business.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en: This is 32-year-old Kadiatu.  She is married and has two children, ages 13 and 9. In 1999, Kadiatu established her plastic wares, flasks and basket business. She began her business because she didn't want to be dependent on her husband anymore; instead, she wanted to be self-sufficient. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,700,000 a month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Kadiatu requires the loan in order to buy a cooler, dishes, and baskets. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 1,200,000. In the future, Kadiatu plans to open another business in a nearby village, to ease the constraints of customers coming from afar and put one of her cousins to work. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy dishes, baskets and other equipment for her business.

loans.name: Madht Group

texts.en:
Madht is a group that consists five women and one man who live in Aden, Yemen. They took out a loan of 330000 YER.
Nwal is a 46-year-old single woman who is happy to be a part of this group. She distributes women's clothing, perfumes and incense. She started the business with a small amount, in order to earn more profit. She loves her work and hopes to continue. Her portion of this group loan is 60,000 YER, which she will use to continue buying fabrics, perfumes and incense.

loans.use: to continue buying fabrics, perfumes and incense for her business.

loans.name: Ellen T.

texts.en:
Ellen T. is 33 years old, single and has two children aged three and seven, who are currently in school. She has been involved in the sale of used clothes for the past four years; she sells children's clothes for both boys and girls.

With the loan given to her, she is going to purchase more used clothes so as to increase her sales. She makes a profit when she sells, especially during the Christmas season, and she also helps with the household expenditure of the family. She has requested this loan to purchase used clothes for the business. Her plan for the future is to buy land and build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase used clothes for the business.

loans.name: Yadira Esther

texts.es: Yadira  compró 3 play Station y un tambor de aceite con el cual generó más ingresos a su negocio, porque fortaleció sus dos negocios. En la actualidad  está aplicando a un nuevo credikiva, porque la juventud que atiende requiere cambios constantes y ella necesita comprar CD para actualizar sus juegos, adicionalmente tiene muchos mas pedidos de aceite y también comprará 6 tambores. Ella está muy entusiasmada porque el lugar donde tiene su negocio ha potencializado su oferta, debido a que arreglaron la vía y es por ella, donde transitan los conductores de motocicletas  que  son sus principales clientes, lo cual hace que su inversión tenga éxito. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente. “Estoy muy agradecida por el apoyo que me han dado en mis últimos créditos, con ellos he logrado organizar cada vez mas mi negocio y gracias por ayudarme a cumplir mis sueños. “
texts.en:
Yadira bought 3 Playstations and one oil drum with which she generated more profits for her business because it strengthened her two businesses. 

Currently, she is applying for a new Kiva loan because the youngsters she attends require constant changes and she needs to buy CDs to upgrade her games. In addition, she has a lot of orders for orders for oil and she will also buy six oil drums. She is very enthusiastic because the location in which her business is located has strengthened what she offers, thanks to the repair of the road along which a lot of motor cyclists, who are her main customers, drive through. All of which makes sure that her investment is successful. 

Her message to Kiva loan lenders: "I am very grateful for the support that you have given me in my last few loans. With these loans, I have been able to organize my business that little bit more every time. Thank you for helping me to make my dreams a reality."

loans.use: to buy CDs to upgrade games, as well as to buy 6 oil drums to meet orders for oil.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 39-year-old Fatmata. She is married, and has three children aged 18,14 and 11. In 1990, Fatmata established her palm-oil and vegetable oil business. She began her business because she wanted to meet her own domestic commitment by taking good care of her children and their welfare. Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Fatmata requires a loan in order to buy palm oil and vegetable oil in large quantities. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 600,000. In the future, Fatmata plans to give her children the best education. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy huge quantities of palm and vegetable oil.

loans.name: Iriani

texts.en:
Iriani is a 44-year-old mother of four. She runs a store which sell house linens, baby items, lingerie and fashion accessories. She has taken bookkeeping courses and is known for her organization and healthy management skills. Her store is well known in her village. She keeps an eye out for upcoming trends and makes sure to bring items her customers are seeking. Iriani is renovating her shop and expanding the area for baby items.

She needed this loan to purchase a showcase window, a sunshade/awning, a storefront sign, to pay for expansion of the area for baby items and to purchase stock for her store.

Iriani has succeeded in developing her store. The shop is located in an area of her home lot. She is interested in continuing to expand and ensuring increased income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a showcase window, a sunshade/awning, a storefront sign, to pay for expansion of the area for baby items and to purchase stock for her store.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: This is Hawa, 39 years old.  She is married and has 4 children, aged 19, 16, 14 and 12. She has four additional dependents who live with her as younger sisters.  In 2000, Hawa established her ladies' handbags business. She began her business because her husband did not care for her and the children. Since she wants her children to be brought up well, she decided to go into business to gain her own source of revenue. Working 6 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about Le 800,000 a month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Hawa needs the loan in order to buy Le 3,000,000 worth of bags. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 500,000. In the future, Hawa plans to establish an outlet for one of her sisters, so that her revenue base will be improved. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy handbags for resale.

loans.name: Katiuska

texts.es: Katiuska, de 27 años, es una señora muy joven y soñadora, ella es madre de un niño de 1 año quien es fruto de su matrimonio con su esposo, ella vive junto a ellos en una casa propia que pudieron comprar con arduo trabajo apoyándose mutuamente y desde ahí todos los días trabajan para tener una mejor calidad de vida. El trabajo de Katiuska consiste en la decoración de fiestas infantiles. Para ello compra diferentes muñecos, letreros decorativos, telas y otros accesorios que usa para desarrollar su labor. En ocasiones compra los materiales ella misma para elaborar todo lo necesario dependiendo del gusto del cliente, del motivo de la fiesta y de la edad de la persona q quien agasajará. Trabaja con ayuda de su hermana o su prima. Sus clientes llegan a ella por recomendación o por conocimiento del trabajo que realiza. Tiene buen gusto para armar figuras llamativas y eso se refleja en todo el ambiente que crea en los eventos que trabaja. Lleva realizando esta actividad más de 1 año y le va muy bien. Anteriormente vendía prendas de vestir a crédito pero la irresponsabilidad de sus compradores al momento del pago terminó por derrumbar su actividad. Ahora le va muy bien y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es la satisfacción que siente al ver el rostro de sus clientes contentos por todo lo que puede crear aún en espacios pequeños, además es un trabajo muy flexible que le permite atender a su pequeño hijo, ahora quiere implementar su negocio con la compra de telas y sillas que se requieren en las fiestas para brindar un mejor servicio y generar otra ganancia por el alquiler de los mismos. Este es el préstamo número 4 con la institución MFP, por ello agradece a las personas que hacen posible su crédito y le dan la oportunidad de continuar trabajando para lograr sus objetivos, está comprometida al pago puntual de sus cuotas con mucha responsabilidad. Con el monto solicitado 1200 soles, comprará muñecos de corcho, adornos, telas, globos, siliconas y otros materiales que usa para decorar.
texts.en:
Katiuska, 27, is a very young dreamer.  She's the mother of a one-year-old son who's the fruit of her marriage to her husband.  She lives with them in her own house, which they managed to buy with hard work, helping each other.  They work every day to have a better quality of life.

Katiuska's job is decorating children's parties.  She buys various dolls, decorative signs, fabric, and other accessories to create her work.  Sometimes she buys the materials herself to make everything, depending on what the customer wants, the reason for the party, and the age of the person being celebrated.

She works with the help of her sister or cousin.  Her customers come to her as referrals or because they're familiar with her work.  She has good taste for putting together attractive figures, and this is reflected in the entire environment she creates for the events she does.  She has been doing this work for a year and it's going very well for her.

Previously she sold clothing on credit, but the irresponsibility of her customers when it came time to pay put an end to her business.  It's going very well for her now.  What she likes about her job is the satisfaction she feels when she sees her customers happy about everything she can create, even in small spaces.  Also, it's a flexible job that allows her to take care of her young son.

Now she wants to supply her business with fabric and chairs for the parties to offer better service and generate additional income by renting them.  This is her fourth loan with MFP.  She's grateful to the people who make her loan possible and give her the opportunity to continue working to achieve her objectives.  She's committed to the responsibility of making her payments punctually.

With the requested loan for 1200 soles [PEN] she'll buy cork dolls, decorations, balloons, silicone products, and other materials to use for decorating.

loans.use: to buy cork dolls, decorations, fabric, balloons, silicone products, and other materials

loans.name: Fatna

texts.en:
Fatna is a 43-year-old mother of three. She is a microentrepreneur who takes the initiative and is determined to build a better life for her family. When a new elementary school was opened in her neighborhood, she got approval from the municipality and the school to open a snack bar for the kids and teachers. In Israel, schools do not have cafeterias or school-run snack bars. Instead, outside businesses can sell snacks and other items to school children and teachers on breaks. In many villages, small kiosks are set up to meet this demand, and they provide popular food and drinks before classes and during the food break. 

Fatna needed this loan to upgrade her snack bar and meet the demand from the students and teachers. With the loan proceeds, she was able to purchase a coffee machine, an iced drink refrigerator, a stove and additional materials for her snack bar.

Fatna has always worked in cash and is now reporting her income and continuing to grow. As her business expands, she wants to hire staff, with the hope of including her eldest son so he can save money to get married one day.

loans.use: to upgrade her snack bar and purchase a coffee machine, an iced drink refrigerator, a stove and additional materials for her snack bar.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah lives in the Kongowea area of Coast province, Kenya. She is married and has four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a tailoring business, which she has been operating for six years.

She learned about Milango through a friend who invited her to the group, and she joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve the business operations. The challenges she is facing are price fluctuation, inflation and a seasonal market.

Leah is applying for a loan of 21,450 Kenyan shillings to buy sewing threads and rolls of material for sewing. The extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve the living standard of the family and pay for her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy sewing threads and rolls of material for sewing.

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley lives in Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He is married and has three children. 

He owns a tea tree farming business. He started the business from the income of subsistence farming.  He also grows potatoes, maize, and vegetables in small scale. The extract from tea tree is used to manufacture cosmetics.

He learned about Milango through an employee who invited him to the group, and he joined with an aim of accessing credit. The main challenges he faces are finding customers and seasonal weather. This he believes will be sorted once he purchases a water pump.

Stanley is applying for a loan of KES 36,700 to buy tea tree seedlings for the business. His extra income from the loan will be added to the savings to pay for his children’s school fees. 

His future plan in five years' time is to do large-scale farming and open butchery.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for his business.

loans.name: Sally

texts.en:
Sally lives in the Kongowea area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is married and has one child. She owns a green grocery, a business which she has been operating for two years.

She learned about Milango through friends who invited her to the group, and she joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main challenge is lack of enough funds. 

Sally is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenya shillings to buy vegetables and fruits wholesale. Her extra income from the loan will be added to her savings, which will in turn improve the living standard of her family. Her dream is to see her business expand to a larger grocery stall.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruits wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add stock of meat.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan lives in the Mariakani area of Coast Province, Kenya. He is married and has one child. He owns a green grocery that he has been operating for three years. He sells fruits and vegetables.

He learned about Milango through friends and joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve his business operations. His main challenge has been lack of funds for business operations.

Hassan is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenya shillings to buy mangoes, oranges, etc. His extra income from the loan will be added to his savings to improve the living standard of his family. His dream is to build a residential house.

loans.use: To buy mangoes, oranges, etc.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is a resident of Mariakani, Kenya. She is also a married mother of five children. Emily owns a grocery stall, selling fruits and vegetables. She began the business from her savings.

Emily is applying for a loan of 73,050 Kenya shillings to purchase foodstuffs for the grocery stall. Her business faces the slight challenge of a seasonal business climate and inflation.  

Through the savings she expects from this loan, she would like to own a larger hotel in the future in the likes of major players in the field in Mariakani.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for the grocery stall.

loans.name: José Luis

texts.es: José invirtió su anterior credikiva en bicicletas estáticas y maquinarias con lo que fortaleció su oferta. Desde que recibió su crédito, su negocio ha crecido y se siente muy satisfecho. Su principal novedad es que sus hijas mayores están estudiando una carrera universitaria y esa es su mayor alegría. En la actualidad está aplicando a un nuevo credikiva con el cual comprará bicicletas elípticas, para responder a la demanda de jóvenes que requieren hacer ejercicios aerobicos de pie y necesitan endurecer sus musculos. Su meta mas adelante es lograr adquirir su propia vivienda y comprar un local para darle una formalidad y posicionamiento a su negocio. Ella dice a sus financiadores de Kiva:  “Estoy muy agradecida” y les pide “que sigan apoyando a nosotros los pequeños comerciantes”. “
texts.en: Jose invested his previous loan in exercise bicycles and machinery with which he strengthened his offer. Since he received the loan, his business has grown and he feels very satisfied. His main news is that his older daughters are studying a university course and this is his greatest happiness. Currently, he is applying for a new loan with which he will buy elliptical machines to respond to demand from young people who need to do standing aerobic exercise and need to toughen their muscles. His goal in the future is to manage to acquire his own home and to buy a shop to give formality and positioning to his business. He says to his Kiva lenders: "I am very thankful" and he asks them to "keep supporting us small business people."

loans.use: to buy elliptical machines.

loans.name: Claudia Elizabeth

texts.es:
Claudia, vive con sus hijos, su madre, ella es la que atiende un negocio de venta de productos de primera necesidad, desde hace ocho años tiene el negocio y cuenta con una gran variedad de productos, la atiende todos los días y su ventaja es que el negocio está ubicado en una localidad muy poblada.

Ella solicita un préstamo para comprarse productos para la tienda por ejemplo pastas, embutidos, aceite, pan, galletas y boquitas, esto le permitirá mejorar el negocio e incrementar su inventario para poder tener lo que los clientes necesitan.

El objetivo es buscar las alternativas financieras que sean necesarias para poder dar su negocio la capacidad y asimismo atender a sus clientes, ya que esto es aumentar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Claudia lives with her children and her mother. She works in the business, selling basic necessity products. She has had the business for eight years and has a wide variety of products. She works every day and the advantage is that the business is located in a very populated area. 

She is asking for the loan to buy products for the store. For example, she will buy pasta, deli meats, oil, bread, cookies and snacks. This will allow her to improve her business and grow her inventory to have what the customers need.

The objective is to seek alternative financing needed to enable her business to better serve her customers and also increase her income.

loans.use: to buy pasta, deli meats, oil, bread, cookies and snacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to complete website development.

loans.name: Khusi Group

texts.en:
“Khusi” (happiness), a Joint Liability Group, was formed in the year 2010 by six active women of Bhawanipatna town of Kalahandi district in Odisha, India. Kalahandi district is known for drought and backwardness. K.Sarojini is one of the members of this group, standing in the middle with raised hand. She is a very energetic lady with advanced thinking. She is 35 years old and lives with her husband, one son of 18 years and one daughter of 20 years who are continuing their studies. Presently, K.Sarojini is residing in a small house with her family. 

K.Sarojini is running a 'Tiffin' business in two places of Bhawanipatna town with the help of two push carts, together with her husband for last 20 years. She prepares Tiffin items like 'dosa' and 'idli' which are very popular in the town. To help her in the business she has engaged two workers (one male and one female). She also takes contracts for supply of Tiffin at social functions. K.Sarojini earns a monthly income of 6000 INR. 

This is the third loan from Mahashakti Foundation and K.Sarojini wants to purchase a freezer and a grinding machine out of this loan. This will help her to store the residue of raw materials after the end of the day to be used in the next day and prepare fresh raw materials, thereby it will save the food product losses due to lack of a good preservation facility.

K.Sarojini hopes to open a quality Tiffin hotel in the heart of the town and construct a 'pucca' house for her family. The other five members of the group are Sabitri, Banita, Bisakha, Kshiti and Urmila who are running a photocopy center, an electricals shop, a cloth store, a Tiffin hotel and a fast food centre.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing a freezer and a grinding machine.

loans.name: Jenny Margot

texts.es:
Jenny tiene 29 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 4 hijos a su cargo. Vive en casa propia con su conviviente y sus 4 hijos. La casa está ubicada en el Caserío Casanas perteneciente al Distrito de Chulucanas. Clienta vive en la parte rural del distrito, pero cuenta con servicio de luz.

La actividad que desarrolla Jenny es la crianza de ganado menor (cabras y cerdos), los cuales al alcanzar peso y tamaño ideal los comercializa en el mercado local. Cuenta con más de 10 años de experiencia en esta actividad. Su cónyuge se dedica a la agricultura, cuenta con un pequeño predio propio y también trabaja como peón.  Con los ingresos que perciben ambos, sacan adelante a su hogar. 

Jenny desea comprar alimento balanceado para su ganado, es por ello que ha creído conveniente obtener un préstamo de 900 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
Jenny is 29 years old and has a live-in partner and four dependent children. She lives in her own house with her spouse and children. The house is located in the village of Casanas in the district of Chulucanas. She lives in the rural part of the district, but she has electricity.

Jenny makes a living raising livestock (goats and pigs), which she sells in the local market when they have reached their ideal weight and size. She has been working in this field for more than 10 years. Her spouse works in agriculture; he has a small piece of land and he also works as a farm laborer. With their combined income, they are able to maintain their home.

Jenny would like to buy balanced feed for her livestock, so she decided to obtain a loan of 900 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: To buy balanced feed for her livestock.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
When Richard lost his job in 2001, he had a difficult time finding new work and experienced several years of unemployment. Instead of being discouraged, he saw this as an opportunity to better use his skills and follow his dream of starting his own business.

Ramsky Machinery is a specialty shop that purchases, reconditions and sells metal working machinery. As the sole owner of the business, Richard strives to introduce his customers to the most innovative machinery, and his biggest reward is when a customer uses new technologies and machinery to increase productivity and save money.

Richard is actively working to secure more customers and is currently working a night job to supplement his income. He recently acquired a new, large client contract and hopes that this opportunity will allow him to grow his business to the point where he will be able to quit his night job and focus 100 percent of his energy on his company.

Richard will use his $3,000 Kiva loan to purchase a company truck that will allow him fulfill the new contract and attract additional business. He ultimately hopes that the increased business opportunities from the truck will stabilize his income and prepare him and his wife for retirement in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a company vehicle.

loans.name: Stewart

texts.en:
Stewart admits he didn’t know too much about the field when he first tried construction as a career in 2008. As he struggled to uphold his business, he never gave up, continued to bid on jobs, and worked with what he learned to get his company to where he is now. 

For the past 20 years, Stewart worked with rebar as he maintained side jobs in retail management, and in the last two years, he changed his career path to devote his time completely to construction. His company, Construction B&N Rebar Contractors, based out of his hometown of Hallsville, Texas, is a placement and tile company. Stewart said they place tile according to the contractors’ aspect. General contractors provide the rebar and he and his team place it down for concrete. 

Since he is not a general contractor, Stewart has to bid on jobs and rebar, which he purchases, and then groups it by the ton. This allows him to charge an economical rate to his clients, which aids to winning more bids and obtaining more job projects for his seven employees. Depending on the size of the job, Stewart hires construction workers to assist on a particular project. Because of the large amount of projects he has, Stewart needed a loan to cover payroll expenses.

After hearing about Accion Texas Inc. through the Small Business Association in Longview, where he attended a couple of seminars, Stewart decided to apply for a loan to sustain his employees on the payroll roster instead of selling his business to make ends meet. 

“I’ve been blessed with a pretty good job,” Stewart said. “I know rebar, and I can help someone put some food on the table for their families.”

loans.use: to pay employees and sustain jobs.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia, tiene 31 años, es una mujer muy alegre y trabajadora, convive con Omer y junto a él tiene 2 hijos de 9 y 2 años de edad. Vive en la casa de su madre junto a su pareja y sus hijos además de sus hermanos y cuñados. La actividad de Julia consiste en la venta de gaseosas y cervezas bien heladas, de manera constante recibe en su casa al representante de la empresa distribuidora quien se encarga de anotar su pedido para que al día siguiente le envíen la cantidad solicitada de acuerdo a su capital, luego sencillamente los coloca en su congelador y espera la llegada de sus eventuales clientes que acuden a ella en busca de obtener la bebida más refrescante para calmar la sed que les produce el intenso calor que caracteriza a su ciudad. Trabaja sola por más de 2 años y su inversión semanal varía de 350 a 400 soles. Si bien es cierto que su negocio le produce buenos ingresos económicos, siente que aún es poco para alcanzar cubrir sus principales gastos en su hogar y es por ello que quiere reflotar su tienda de abarrotes que tenía anteriormente y que tuvo que cerrar por motivos de salud que requerían de su atención e inversión, con ello espera mejorar su economía, por lo pronto está ahorrando parte de los dividendos que obtiene de la venta de gaseosas y cervezas para que pueda concretar esta nueva meta por el bien de su familia. Este es el crédito numero 3 con MFP, por ello se siente agradecida con las personas que le brindan el financiamiento que necesita para que pueda concretar sus planes, por otro lado se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de manera puntual y espera continuar trabajando con su banco comunal por el compañerismo y la solidaridad que muestran entre ellos cada uno de sus integrantes.
Con el monto solicitado (S/. 1300), comprará mayor cantidad de gaseosas y cervezas para continuar vendiendo y obtener más ganancias
texts.en:
Julia is 31 years old. She is a very happy and hard-working woman. She lives with Omer, with whom she has two children, ages 2 and 9. She lives in her mother's house with her partner and her children, as well as her siblings and in-laws.

Julia makes a living selling chilled soft drinks and beer. The representative of the distributing company visits her regularly to take her orders, so that the next day they send her the requested amounts according to her capital. Afterwards, she simply places the drinks in her freezer and waits for her clients to arrive. They come to her in search of the most refreshing drink to quench the thirst created by the intense heat of their city.

Julia has been working alone for more than 2 years, and her weekly investment varies from 350 to 400 soles. While her business produces a good income, she feels that it is still too low to cover the main expenses of her home. Therefore, she would like to relaunch the grocery store which she previously had, which she had to close for health reasons that required her attention and funds. In this way, she hopes to improve her finances. She is saving some of the income which she obtains from the sale of soft drinks and beer in order to realize this new goal for the sake of her family.

This is her third loan with MFP, and she is very grateful for the people who give her the financing that she needs to realize her plans. On the other hand, she is committed to making her payments on time, and she hopes to continue working with her communal bank because of the feeling of community and solidarity which the members share with each other.

With the amount she is asking for (1300 soles), she will buy a greater quantity of soft drinks and beer in order to continue selling and make more profit.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and beer.

loans.name: William Eduardo

texts.es:
William tiene 22 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 1 hijo a su cargo. Vive en casa propia, la cual está ubicada en el caserío San Pedrillo perteneciente al Distrito de Tambogrande. Cliente vive en la parte rural del distrito y no cuenta con los servicios básicos.

La actividad que desarrolla es la crianza de ganado menor, los cuales engorda y luego vende en el mercado local a peso vivo. También trabaja en la chacra de su padre, en donde tiene plantas de limón en producción. Cuenta con más de 02 años de experiencia en la ganadería y agricultura.  Adicionalmente trabaja como peón estable en un fundo agrícola del sector.  

William desea comprar alimento balanceado para su ganado, es por ello que ha creído conveniente obtener un préstamo de 1000 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
William is 22 years old. He has a live-in partner and one child. He lives in his own house, which is located in the village of San Pedrillo in the district of Tambogrande. He lives in the rural part of the district and does not have access to basic services.

He makes a living raising livestock, which he fattens up and sells in the local market. He also works on his father's farm, where he has lemon plants. He has more than two years of experience in agriculture and raising livestock. Additionally, he works as a laborer on one of the area's farms.

William would like to buy balanced feed for his livestock, so he decided to obtain a loan of 1000 nuevo soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: To buy balanced feed for his livestock.

loans.name: Lida

texts.es: Lida, de 40 años es una mujer honesta, responsable y muy trabajadora, convive con Amador y junto a él tiene 3 hijos de 11, 8 y 2 años de edad, vive en su casa propia y comparte sus días con su cónyuge, sus hijos y su suegra compartiendo día a día su lucha por salir adelante. El trabajo de Lida consiste en brindar servicio de vulcanizado. Tiene su taller propio instalado en su casa en donde ofrece diversos servicios como parchado de llantas, reparación vehículos, bajada de motores, tejido de aro, centrado de aro entre otros. Trabaja con ayuda de su cónyuge y de otro ayudante. Su principal labor se centra en la administración del servicio. Lleva en este negocio 2 años atendiendo desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche. Ahora esta viendo la posibilidad de vender bebidas como gaseosas y cervezas debido a la demanda de sus clientes quienes le solicitan estos productos mientras esperan la culminación del servicio en sus vehículos. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es el trato directo que tiene con sus clientes, le agrada ver su trabajo final y que ello contribuya a que sus clientes también trabajen mejor, le agrada además compartir y desarrollar está pasión con su cónyuge y eso la motiva a seguir adelante. Espera implementar pronto su taller para continuar trabajando con mejores resultados y además empezar a vender bebidas. Este es el crédito número 3 con MFP, está muy emocionada y agradecida por el respaldo económico que le ofrecen para continuar con sus planes, no quiere dejar de pagarlo por falta de dinero y es por eso que se compromete a ser muy puntual y sobre todo muy responsable, está muy contenta de continuar con este grupo ya que son muy cumplidos y amables. Con el monto solicitado (S/. 1500) comprará repuestos de motos y mototaxis y algunas herramientas que usa en su trabajo, además con 500 soles quiere comprar gaseosas y cervezas para empezar a vender en su casa.
texts.en: Lida, 40, is an honest, responsible and very hard working woman. She lives with Amador and together they have three children who are 11, 8 and 2 years old. She lives in her own house and shares her days with her partner, their children and her mother-in-law sharing daily their fight to get ahead. Lida's work consists of providing vulcanizing services. She has her own shop installed in her house where she offers different services like patching tires, repairing cars, lowering motors, fabric rings, centering rings, among others. She works with the help of her spouse and another assistant. Her main job centers on managing the service. For two years she's been attending to this business from 7AM until 10PM. Now, she is seeing the possibility to sell drinks like sodas and beers due to the demand of her customers who ask her for these products while they wait for the car service to be completed. What she likes about her job is the direct relationship that she has with her customers. It pleases her to see the final work and that it contributes to her customers' also working better. It also pleases her to share and develop this passion with her spouse and that motivates her to keep going. She hopes soon to start a shop to continue working with better results and also to begin to sell drinks. This is her third loan with MFP. She is very excited and thankful for the economic backing that you offer her to continue with her plans. She doesn't want to stop paying due to lack of money and it is for this that she promises to be very punctual and, above all, very responsible. She is very content to continue with this group since they are very accomplished and friendly. With the amount requested (S 1500) she will buy car and mototaxi parts and some tools that she uses in her work. Also, with 500 soles she wants to buy sodas and beers to start to sell from her house.

loans.use: to buy car and mototaxi parts and some tools.

loans.name: Jay Matadi Group

texts.en:
Jay Matadi, a Joint Liability Group, was formed in the year 2010 by four active women of Bolangir town of Bolangir district in Odisha, India with a purpose to take loans from Mahashakti Foundation to enhance their business to add some extra income to their families. Anandini is one of the members of this group, standing on the extreme left with raised hand. She is a very active and confident lady. She is 33 years of old and lives with her husband and two children who are continuing their primary education.

Anandini has been running a fast food center in Bolangir town with the help of her husband for last 20 years. Her fast food center starts at 3.00 pm and continues up to 9.00 pm where mainly she sells 'chart' (a fast food item). Her preparation is very popular in the town. To help her in the business she has engaged three workers. Anandini earns a monthly income of 7000 INR. 

This is the 2nd loan from Mahashakti Foundation and Anandini wants to purchase stock of oil, dough, potatoes, gram (lentils) etc. to save money from frequent transporting and price hikes due to rate fluctuation. 

Anandini hopes to add sweet items along with her present business. She is also very much interested to give better education to her children. The other three members of the group are Nirupama, Usha and Lilirani who are running a ladies' fancy item center, tailoring and coaching center, and a betel nut center respectively. Anandini has been heading the group from the beginning with sincerity and good leadership.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing sugar, oil, dough, gram (lentils), etc.

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is a resident of the Kongowea area of Coast province, Kenya. She is married and has five children, of whom four attend school. 

She owns a charcoal business that has been in operation for the last six years. Apart from this business, she earns income from the business of farming.

Dama learnt about Milango through a friend and joined the organization with an aim of accessing credit to improve the operations of her business. Her main challenge is high transport costs.
